So said  Curt Sampson  on  1/25/2003 --------------------

>On Thu, 23 Jan 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
>> >But in the end, I guess you believe in test-first programming or
you
>> don't.
>>
>> Not necessarily. There's no TDD licence. You can do it sometimes and
>> not other times. I only wish that those who choose this approach
>> measure the difference between the two.
>
>Well, for me the measure is pretty easy. I no longer spend ten minutes
>working out the interface for a class only to discover that it's a
nice
>interface, but not the interface I need.

AHA! Let the record show...

>In fact, quite often these days, I find myself practicing
"test-second,
>implementation-third" programming. I'll be in the middle of
programming
>a servlet, and I'll realize I need to be able to find, say, a Foo
object
>based on the current IP address of the request. At that point, I'll
just
>make up, on the spot, the most convenient interface for that, and use
>it, even though that interface, and possibly not even the object I'm
>using, exists.
<snip />

This is a great approach. I would say this: if only you were working
Smalltalk or Ruby, you could skip the "interface" bit and just writing
something -- anything -- to hold the method you need. Then you
test-drive that thing. Then you identify how to refactor it into the
framework. Very, very cool.

>I used to be a very bottom-up programmer, but the speed and ease of
this
>top-down approach has completely converted me. I now write probably
one
>half to one third the amount of code I used to write to get equivalant
>functionality in an application. My customers really appreciate this.

I will do this religiously and yell at you if it fails me. :)

J. B. Rainsberger,
